content: Yes, the different types of lava definitely affect the appearance and behavior of the volcanoes. Basaltic lava, which is more fluid and has lower viscosity, tends to produce broad, gentle shield volcanoes with gently sloping sides. These volcanoes can be quite large and involve extensive flows of lava. Andesitic lava, on the other hand, is more viscous and forms steep-sided, conical volcanoes, such as the ones found on the Big Island of Hawaii. These volcanoes tend to produce explosive eruptions with ash clouds and pyroclastic flows. The type of lava also affects the length of eruptions, with basaltic volcanoes often experiencing long-lasting, effusive eruptions, while andesitic volcanoes tend to have shorter, explosive eruptions.
